title: Grizzly Bear!
text: A massive grizzly rears up on its hind legs just 30 yards away! Lewis described grizzlies as 'a most tremendous looking animal.' What do you do?

choices.text: ğŸ‹ Stand tall and shout together!
choices.result: The bear studies your noisy group, snorts, and lumbers away. Grizzlies often back down from groups â€” Lewis learned this after being chased into the Missouri River alone!

choices.text: ğŸŒŠ Back slowly toward the river
choices.result: The bear loses interest and wanders off. Smart â€” the Corps used the river as an escape route more than once.

choices.text: ğŸƒ Run for the trees!
choices.result: Running triggers the bear's chase instinct! It pursues you for 50 yards before giving up. Never run from a grizzly â€” they can sprint 35 mph!

title: Buffalo Herd Crossing!
text: Thousands of buffalo are swimming across the Missouri directly in your path. The massive herd stretches a mile wide! Clark wrote the herds were 'so numerous they darkened the plains.'

choices.text: â¸ï¸ Pull ashore and wait them out
choices.result: You wait two hours as the herd passes. The men use the time to hunt a straggler for 400 pounds of meat. Patience pays off!

choices.text: ğŸš£ Paddle straight through the herd!
choices.result: A panicked bull clips your pirogue! Water pours in and you lose a bag of flour. Buffalo weigh up to 2,000 pounds â€” never challenge them in the water.

choices.text: ğŸ¯ Hunters out â€” fresh meat!
choices.result: Drouillard drops two bulls from the bank. That's over 1,600 pounds of meat! The Corps often took advantage of crossing herds to stock up.

title: Rattlesnake Nest!
text: Youâ€™ve stumbled onto a rocky ledge alive with prairie rattlesnakes! Clark counted â€˜no fewer than 10 snakes in a single afternoon.â€™ Based on the expedition journals, how did the Corps handle snake encounters?

choices.text: ğŸªµ Use long poles to sweep them aside and move carefully through
choices.result: Thatâ€™s what the Corps did! They used long sticks to clear snakes from the trail. Lewis carefully preserved several specimens to send back to Jefferson â€” even danger became science.

choices.text: ğŸ’¥ Shoot them all â€” we have plenty of ammunition
choices.result: Wasting ammunition on snakes would be reckless. The Corps needed every bullet for hunting and defense. Powder and lead were irreplaceable â€” they couldnâ€™t resupply until they returned to St. Louis.

choices.text: ğŸ›‘ Turn back and find a completely different route
choices.result: On narrow mountain trails, detours could cost days. The Corps pushed through hazards when they could, saving their limited time and energy. They treated snake bites with bark poultices when needed.

title: Bald Eagle on the Bluff!
text: A magnificent bald eagle circles overhead, then lands on a cottonwood snag near camp. Lewis, a devoted naturalist, is eager to document it. What do you do?

choices.text: ğŸ“ Sketch it and note its markings
choices.result: You record its wingspan, coloring, and diet â€” just as Lewis did. His detailed scientific notes described over 170 new species for American science!

choices.text: ğŸ”« Shoot it for a specimen
choices.result: You collect the specimen. Lewis did shoot birds for study â€” it was standard practice for naturalists in 1805. Science was different then.

choices.text: ğŸ«¢ Ignore it â€” we have miles to cover
choices.result: Lewis would never pass up a new specimen! Jefferson personally instructed him to document all wildlife. Science was half the mission's purpose.

title: Prairie Dog Town!
text: You've discovered a vast prairie dog colony stretching across five acres! The little animals bark and dive into their burrows. Lewis wants to send a live one back to President Jefferson.

choices.text: ğŸ’§ Pour water down a burrow to flush one out
choices.result: After hauling five barrels of water, one soggy prairie dog emerges! This is exactly what the Corps did â€” they sent it alive all the way to Jefferson in Washington!

choices.text: ğŸª¤ Set a small snare at the burrow entrance
choices.result: The prairie dog avoids the trap easily. Their burrows have multiple exits. The Corps tried digging them out first â€” it took hours and failed.

choices.text: ğŸ¥„ Dig one out by hand
choices.result: You dig six feet down and the burrow keeps going! The Corps dug for hours before giving up. These burrows can run 15 feet deep with multiple chambers.

title: Thunderstorm on the Plains!
text: A violent storm rolls in fast. Black clouds pile up and lightning forks across the open prairie. There is no shelter for miles in any direction!

choices.text: â›º Make camp in a low, flat area
choices.result: Good call. You stay low, away from high ground and lone trees. The Corps weathered dozens of prairie storms by staying low and spreading out.

choices.text: ğŸŒ³ Shelter under the tallest tree
choices.result: Lightning strikes the tree with a deafening crack! Never shelter under tall isolated trees in a storm â€” they attract lightning.

choices.text: ğŸ§­ Push forward through the storm
choices.result: Soaked and miserable, but still moving. The Corps often had no choice but to march through storms for days on end. Clark called it 'disagreeable beyond description.'

title: Hailstorm at the Great Falls!
text: Hailstones the size of apples crash down! Clarkâ€™s journal describes hail â€˜seven inches in circumferenceâ€™ that knocked men to the ground. He and Sacagawea barely survived â€” where did they shelter?

choices.text: ğŸ”ï¸ Under rock ledges along the bluffs
choices.result: Thatâ€™s where Clark took cover â€” but a flash flood nearly drowned them in the ravine below the ledge! He pushed Sacagawea and baby Jean Baptiste up the cliff as water rose to his waist. The hailstorm and flood together nearly ended the expedition.

choices.text: â¬‡ï¸ In the ravine below â€” itâ€™s sheltered from the wind
choices.result: Deadly mistake! A flash flood roared through that exact ravine during this storm. Clark, Sacagawea, and her baby were nearly swept away. Low ground near the Great Falls is a death trap during storms.

choices.text: ğŸ›¶ Under the overturned boats for protection
choices.result: The boats provided some cover from the hail, and the men who stayed with the boats were bruised but safe. Clark wrote the hailstones left â€˜the men bleeding and their bodies much battered.â€™

title: Bitter Cold at Fort Mandan!
text: It is January 1805 at Fort Mandan. Temperatures plunge to minus 45 degrees Fahrenheit. Sentinel duty could mean death by frostbite. How does the party survive?

choices.text: ğŸ”¥ Keep roaring fires day and night
choices.result: The fires burn through enormous amounts of wood, but everyone survives. At Fort Mandan, the men chopped firewood constantly for five straight months.

choices.text: ğŸ§¥ Double up in shared bedrolls
choices.result: Body heat plus buffalo robes does the trick. The Mandan people taught the Corps to use layered buffalo hides, which trapped warmth far better than wool blankets.

choices.text: ğŸƒ Keep marching to stay warm
choices.result: Marching in minus 45 wastes energy dangerously fast. Several men get frostbite on their toes and fingers. Lewis noted that exposed skin 'froze in minutes.'

title: Scorching Heat on the Plains!
text: It is midsummer and the treeless plains offer no shade. The temperature soars past 100 degrees. Men are stumbling from heat exhaustion and the water supply is low.

choices.text: ğŸŒ… March at dawn and dusk, rest at midday
choices.result: Wise. You cover the same distance with half the suffering. Plains tribes had traveled this way for generations â€” the Corps learned to adapt.

choices.text: ğŸ’ª Push through â€” we're behind schedule
choices.result: Private Whitehouse collapses from heatstroke. You lose more time caring for him than you would have lost resting. Lewis learned this lesson the hard way.

choices.text: ğŸ•ï¸ Find a creek bottom and camp early
choices.result: You find a shaded bend with cool water. The men recover their strength and make excellent time the next morning. Sometimes resting is the fastest way forward.

title: Mosquito Swarm!
text: Clouds of mosquitoes descend on camp at dusk! Clark wrote he â€˜could not keep them off my gun long enough to take aim.â€™ Lewis called them â€˜the most tormenting of all insects.â€™ How did the Corps actually fight back?

choices.text: ğŸ”¥ Burn green wood to create thick smoke screens
choices.result: Exactly right! Smudge fires using green wood were the Corpsâ€™ primary defense. The smoke drove mosquitoes away just enough for the men to eat and sleep. Lewis noted this was the ONLY effective remedy.

choices.text: ğŸ§´ Smear animal grease on all exposed skin
choices.result: The Corps did use bear grease as a repellent! It helped somewhat, though it attracted its own problems. Combined with the smoke fires, it gave partial relief from what Lewis called an â€˜almost intolerableâ€™ torment.

choices.text: ğŸ¤· Endure them â€” thereâ€™s nothing anyone can do
choices.result: The Corps were resourceful survivors, not passive victims! They tried smoke fires, animal grease, netting, and sleeping in shifts. Giving up wasnâ€™t in their nature â€” they adapted to every challenge.

title: Prickly Pear Cactus Field!
text: The portage trail is carpeted with prickly pear cactus. Spines punch through double-soled moccasins! Lewis called them â€˜one of the greatest pests of the plains.â€™ What made the Great Falls portage uniquely terrible?

choices.text: ğŸœï¸ Cactus, sharp rocks, AND rattlesnakes â€” all at once across 18 brutal miles
choices.result: Exactly. The portage combined every hazard at once: thorns piercing moccasins, jagged rocks cutting feet, rattlesnakes in the path, scorching heat, and grizzly bears nearby. The men went through dozens of moccasins and called it the worst stretch of the entire journey.

choices.text: ğŸ» The men were already weakened from fighting grizzly bears
choices.result: While grizzlies were a danger throughout, the portageâ€™s real challenge was the 18-mile gauntlet of cactus, rocks, and extreme heat. The men hauled thousands of pounds of gear on crude cottonwood-wheel carts through it all.

choices.text: ğŸ¥¾ They had no footwear left at all
choices.result: They had moccasins, but nothing was thick enough! The men doubled and tripled their moccasin soles and still bled. They went through so many pairs that Sacagawea and the other camp members sewed constantly to keep up with demand.

title: Sickness in Camp!
text: Several men are down with violent stomach cramps and fever. It might be bad water or spoiled meat. Lewis acts as the expedition's doctor â€” he has a medicine chest but no medical degree.

choices.text: ğŸ’Š Administer Dr. Rush's pills
choices.result: The powerful mercury-laced 'Thunderbolts' purge the illness violently. Harsh, but it works. Lewis used Rush's pills throughout the journey â€” archaeologists have found traces of mercury at their campsites!

choices.text: ğŸµ Brew willow bark tea and rest
choices.result: The natural remedy eases the fever slowly. Willow bark contains salicin, similar to aspirin. Native healers had used it for centuries â€” sometimes the old ways work best.

choices.text: ğŸš¶ March on â€” they'll walk it off
choices.result: The sick men collapse on the trail and the whole party is delayed for two days. Lewis learned that ignoring illness always made things worse.

title: Hunting Accident!
text: While hunting in thick willows, one man accidentally shoots another in the hip! This actually happened â€” Private Cruzatte shot Lewis in the buttock, mistaking him for an elk.

choices.text: ğŸ©¹ Clean the wound and pack it with linen
choices.result: You clean the wound, apply a poultice, and bandage it tight. Lewis treated his own gunshot wound this same way and was walking again in three weeks.

choices.text: ğŸ”¥ Cauterize the wound immediately
choices.result: Brutal but it stops the bleeding. Frontier medicine was harsh. The wounded man screams but survives. Infection was the real danger on the trail.

choices.text: ğŸ¤· It's just a scratch â€” let him rest
choices.result: The wound becomes infected within days. Without proper treatment, even minor injuries could become fatal on the frontier. Always treat wounds immediately.

title: Dangerous Rapids Ahead!
text: The river narrows into a roaring chute of white water! Rocks jut from the foam and the canoes are tossing wildly. The men look to you for a decision.

choices.text: âš“ Rope the boats and portage around
choices.result: Safe but exhausting. You lose half a day hauling 8,000 pounds of gear overland. The Corps portaged around the Great Falls for nearly a month â€” covering just 18 miles!

choices.text: ğŸš£ Send the best steersman through first
choices.result: Your lead canoe threads the rapids perfectly and signals the route! The others follow safely. River experience saved the Corps many times.

choices.text: ğŸš£ Charge through all at once!
choices.result: Two canoes collide in the chaos! Gunpowder, medicine, and journals nearly lost to the river. The Corps almost lost everything this way at the Marias River.

title: Fork in the River!
text: The Missouri splits into two equal branches. Your maps show nothing. The north fork looks muddier like the Missouri; the south fork runs clear. Every man in the party votes north. Which way?

choices.text: â¬…ï¸ Take the south fork â€” trust the captains
choices.result: Correct! This happened at the Marias River in June 1805. Every man voted north, but Lewis and Clark chose south â€” reasoning that a mountain-fed river would run clear. They were right!

choices.text: â¡ï¸ Take the north fork â€” trust the vote
choices.result: That's the Marias River â€” a dead end! You'd lose weeks. Lewis trusted his scientific observations over the popular vote. Leaders must sometimes overrule the majority.

choices.text: ğŸ”­ Scout both forks before deciding
choices.result: Smart and cautious! Lewis did exactly this â€” he scouted the south fork for days before committing. Careful observation saved the expedition from a costly mistake.

title: Lost on the Lolo Trail!
text: You are crossing the Bitterroot Mountains and the trail has vanished under deep snow. The horses are starving and the men are eating candle tallow to survive. This was the expedition's darkest hour.

choices.text: ğŸ”ï¸ Follow the ridgeline west
choices.result: Old Toby, your Shoshone guide, finds the Nez Perce trail along the ridge. The high ground is brutal but passable. The Corps nearly starved crossing these mountains â€” it took 11 days.

choices.text: â¬‡ï¸ Drop into the valley for shelter
choices.result: The valleys are choked with fallen timber and deadfall. You waste two days and have to climb back up. The ridgeline was the only way â€” the Nez Perce knew this for generations.

choices.text: ğŸ´ Kill a horse for emergency food
choices.result: Grim but necessary. The Corps did kill and eat colts to survive the Bitterroots. Clark named one camp 'Killed Colt Creek.' Survival sometimes demands hard choices.

title: Flash Flood in the Ravine!
text: While sheltering from rain in a narrow ravine, a wall of brown water suddenly roars down the gully! This nearly killed Clark, Sacagawea, and her baby at the Great Falls!

choices.text: â¬†ï¸ Scramble up the bluff immediately!
choices.result: You claw your way up the muddy slope just as the water surges past. Clark saved Sacagawea and baby Jean Baptiste by pushing them up a cliff face as water rose to his waist!

choices.text: ğŸŒ³ Grab a tree and hold on
choices.result: The tree holds but you are battered by debris for 20 terrifying minutes. You survive, but with cuts and bruises. Flash floods carry logs, boulders, and everything in their path.

choices.text: ğŸƒ Run downstream to outpace it
choices.result: You cannot outrun a flash flood â€” the water moves at 15 mph through narrow ravines. Clark wrote that the water rose 15 feet in minutes. Always go UP.

title: Fallen Timber Everywhere!
text: The Lolo Trail through the Bitterroot Mountains is choked with tangled deadfall. Clark wrote they made â€˜only 12 miles in a full day.â€™ The horses are starving and men are eating candle tallow. What ultimately saved the expedition?

choices.text: ğŸ´ They killed and ate some horses to survive the crossing
choices.result: Tragically true. The Corps killed colts for food, naming one camp â€˜Killed Colt Creek.â€™ It was the expeditionâ€™s darkest hour. But ultimately, reaching the Nez Perce villages on the other side is what truly saved them.

choices.text: ğŸ•ï¸ The Nez Perce people fed them on the far side of the mountains
choices.result: Yes! After 11 days of near-starvation, the Corps stumbled into a Nez Perce village. Chief Twisted Hairâ€™s people fed them â€” though the sudden change to camas root and salmon made nearly everyone violently sick. Once again, Native generosity saved the expedition.

choices.text: ğŸ¦Œ They found a valley full of deer and elk
choices.result: Game was almost nonexistent in the Bitterroots â€” that was the whole problem. The mountains were too dense and snowy for large animals. The Corps' hunters came back empty-handed day after day, which forced the terrible decision to eat their horses.

title: Quicksand on the River!
text: Men are sinking in the Missouriâ€™s shifting sandbars! Lewis noted the men were â€˜frequently up to their armpits in quicksand and water.â€™ What was the Corpsâ€™ main method for moving the heavy keelboat upstream?

choices.text: ğŸš£ Rowing with long oars against the current
choices.result: Rowing helped, but it wasnâ€™t the primary method. The Missouriâ€™s powerful current made rowing upstream nearly impossible for the 55-foot keelboat. The Corps mainly relied on cordelling â€” pulling the boat with ropes from shore.

choices.text: ğŸš¶ Walking along the bank and pulling the boat with ropes
choices.result: Thatâ€™s cordelling â€” the backbreaking reality of upstream travel! Men waded through mud, quicksand, and cold water while hauling ropes attached to the 12-ton keelboat. They cordelled for months, covering just 10â€“15 miles on a good day.

choices.text: â›µ Sailing with favorable winds when possible
choices.result: They did raise sails when the wind cooperated, but winds on the Missouri were unreliable. Cordelling â€” pulling the boat with ropes from shore â€” was the exhausting daily reality. The menâ€™s feet were constantly raw from the rocky riverbed.

title: Meeting the Shoshone!
text: After months of searching, you finally encounter the Shoshone people in the Rocky Mountains. You desperately need horses to cross the Bitterroots. Sacagawea steps forward â€” their chief is her brother Cameahwait!

choices.text: ğŸ´ Trade goods for horses â€” be generous
choices.result: You offer rifles, blankets, and tools for 29 horses. The Shoshone agree! Without these horses, the expedition would have been stranded. Sacagawea's reunion with her brother made it all possible.

choices.text: ğŸ–ï¸ Present medals and flags with ceremony
choices.result: The formal diplomacy impresses Cameahwait. He agrees to trade horses AND provide a guide. Lewis's diplomatic training paid off â€” ceremony and respect opened doors that force never could.

choices.text: ğŸ’ª Demand horses â€” we represent the President!
choices.result: Cameahwait is offended by the arrogance. He refuses to trade. Without Sacagawea smoothing things over, the expedition might have ended right here in the Rockies.

title: Welcome at the Nez Perce Village!
text: Starving and exhausted after crossing the Bitterroots, you stumble into a Nez Perce village. Chief Twisted Hair offers food, but the men gorge themselves on unfamiliar camas root and dried fish.

choices.text: ğŸ½ï¸ Eat small portions slowly
choices.result: Smart! The men who ate slowly stayed healthy. Starved bodies cannot handle sudden large meals. Modern survival training teaches the same lesson.

choices.text: ğŸ¤¤ Feast â€” the men are starving!
choices.result: Nearly the entire Corps becomes violently ill for days! This actually happened â€” the sudden switch to camas root and salmon made almost everyone sick. Lewis could barely stand for a week.

choices.text: ğŸ– Hunt for familiar game meat first
choices.result: You bag a few deer before eating the unfamiliar food. Mixing familiar and new foods helps the stomach adjust. The men who ate game first fared better than those who binged on camas.

title: Mandan Winter: The Forge!
text: It is winter at Fort Mandan. The Mandan and Hidatsa people need metal tools and your blacksmith John Shields can make them. What should you forge to build good relations and resupply?

choices.text: ğŸª“ War hatchets from an old stove
choices.result: The Mandan eagerly trade corn and dried meat for your hatchets! The Corps cut up their iron stove and forged it into trade goods â€” one of the cleverest moves of the expedition.

choices.text: âš”ï¸ Weapons to show strength
choices.result: The Mandan don't need more weapons and the display makes them wary. Trade goods, not threats, built the alliances that kept the Corps alive through winter.

choices.text: ğŸ”§ Repair tools for their canoes and travois
choices.result: Excellent diplomacy! Practical help built genuine friendship. The Mandan shared invaluable knowledge about the river ahead, including warnings about the Great Falls.

title: Salmon Run on the Columbia!
text: You've reached the Columbia River and salmon are running thick â€” thousands of fish choke the shallows. The local Chinook people are expert fishers. How do you resupply?

choices.text: ğŸŸ Trade with the Chinook for dried salmon
choices.result: The Chinook trade generously. Their dried salmon kept the Corps fed for weeks. Lewis admired their fishing weirs and preservation techniques, noting methods far superior to anything he knew.

choices.text: ğŸª¤ Build your own fish traps
choices.result: Your crude traps catch a few fish, but the Chinook's engineered weirs catch hundreds. Sometimes the wise choice is to learn from the experts rather than reinvent the wheel.

choices.text: ğŸ¹ Spear fish from the shallows
choices.result: You land a few good salmon! The men are thrilled. But trading with the Chinook would have yielded ten times the food. Still, fresh salmon over a campfire is hard to beat.

title: Water Supply Running Low!
text: The creek marked on your rough map has dried up. The men's canteens are empty and the nearest river is a full day's march. The July sun beats down mercilessly.

choices.text: ğŸŒ¿ Look for green vegetation in low ground
choices.result: You spot a line of green willows in a dry wash and dig down three feet â€” water seeps in! Plains travelers knew that green plants signal underground water. The Corps used this trick many times.

choices.text: ğŸ¦¬ Follow buffalo trails
choices.result: Buffalo trails often lead to water â€” animals know the land better than any map. You follow the tracks two miles to a hidden spring. Frontier wisdom saved the day!

choices.text: â© March faster to reach the river
choices.result: Pushing hard without water is deadly. Two men collapse from dehydration before you find the river. Clark wrote that lack of water was 'more distressing than hunger.'

title: Broken Pirogue!
text: Your largest canoe has cracked open on a submerged rock! Water pours in and supplies are floating downstream. Sacagawea calmly scoops up irreplaceable journals and instruments from the water.

choices.text: ğŸŒ² Beach it and patch with pine pitch
choices.result: You seal the crack with heated pine resin and elk hide. The Corps repaired boats constantly using whatever was at hand. Pine pitch was the duct tape of 1805!

choices.text: ğŸªµ Build new dugout canoes
choices.result: You fell cottonwoods and hollow them with fire and adze. It takes three days but the new canoes are sturdy. The Corps built dozens of dugout canoes throughout the journey.

choices.text: ğŸ“¦ Abandon the boat and carry supplies on foot
choices.result: Without boats, you cannot move the 8,000 pounds of supplies. The expedition depends on river travel. Lewis called the pirogues 'absolutely essential to the enterprise.'

title: Wolves Circling Camp!
text: Wolves howl from every direction as darkness falls! Clark noted â€˜a great number of wolves about us all night.â€™ Lewis, always the scientist, observed wolves closely following the buffalo herds. Why was this observation important?

choices.text: ğŸ« It revealed the ecological relationship between predator and prey on the plains
choices.result: Lewis was doing early ecology! His observations of wolves trailing buffalo herds documented the predator-prey balance that sustained the Great Plains ecosystem. Jefferson valued these scientific insights as much as maps and routes.

choices.text: âš ï¸ It proved wolves were dangerous predators that threatened the expedition
choices.result: Actually, wolves almost never attacked the Corps. Lewis noted they were surprisingly tolerant of humans. His real interest was scientific: understanding how wolves, buffalo, and the prairie ecosystem worked together. Science was always half the mission.

choices.text: ğŸ’¡ It gave them the idea to follow wolf packs to find buffalo for food
choices.result: Practical thinking! Tracking wolves could lead to buffalo herds. But Lewisâ€™s deeper observation was ecological â€” he was documenting how species interacted in ways unknown to Eastern science. His notes foreshadowed modern ecology by decades.

title: Stargazing for Position!
text: Lewis unpacks his sextant, chronometer, and artificial horizon to take celestial observations. Jefferson ordered precise latitude and longitude readings throughout the journey. How do you help?

choices.text: ğŸ•¯ï¸ Hold the lantern steady for Lewis
choices.result: Lewis sights Polaris and calculates your latitude to within a few miles! His astronomical readings created the first accurate map of the American West. Jefferson considered this data priceless.

choices.text: ğŸ“– Record the readings in the journal
choices.result: Perfect. Clark was the expedition's primary mapmaker and recorder. His measurements and sketches became the basis for every American map of the West for the next 50 years.

choices.text: ğŸ˜´ Turn in early â€” stars can wait
choices.result: Lewis insists this cannot wait â€” a cloudy night tomorrow means lost data forever. Mapping the continent was as important as reaching the Pacific. Science doesn't sleep!

title: Journal Writing by Firelight!
text: Jefferson's orders were clear: record everything. Plants, animals, weather, rivers, and native peoples. Your ink is low and your quill is worn. Tonight you must choose what to document.

choices.text: ğŸŒ¿ Describe the new plant species found today
choices.result: You carefully press a specimen and describe its leaves, flowers, and habitat. Lewis documented over 170 plant species unknown to Western science â€” many still carry names he gave them.

choices.text: ğŸ—ºï¸ Map today's river course and landmarks
choices.result: Clark sketches the river bends, tributaries, and notable bluffs. His maps were astonishingly accurate â€” some were still in use by the U.S. Army 50 years later!

choices.text: ğŸ˜¤ Skip tonight â€” too tired to write
choices.result: Every missed entry is lost knowledge forever. Some of the expedition's most important discoveries were recorded on the hardest, most exhausting days. Lewis and Clark almost never skipped a night.

title: The Great Falls Portage!
text: Five massive waterfalls block the Missouri â€” an 18-mile stretch of roaring cascades. Everything must be carried overland: boats, supplies, weapons, and scientific instruments. The portage took the real Corps 24 brutal days.

choices.text: ğŸ› Build wooden wagon wheels from cottonwood
choices.result: Brilliant! The Corps cut rounds from a cottonwood mast to make crude wheels for a cart. It was backbreaking but moved the heaviest loads. American ingenuity at its finest!

choices.text: ğŸ’ª Carry everything on the men's backs
choices.result: The men stagger under 200-pound loads across cactus, rocks, and rattlesnakes in searing heat. Several collapse. It works, but the wheels would have saved days of agony.

choices.text: ğŸš¢ Try Lewis's iron-frame boat experiment
choices.result: Lewis brought a collapsible iron boat frame from Harper's Ferry for this exact moment. Sadly, without proper pine pitch to seal the elk-skin covering, it sank. A rare failure for the captains!
